tossups.question: A self-portrait by this artist shows him painting a scene of a headless woman herding a red goat. After the death of Dag Hammarskjöld (“dog HA-mar-hweld”), this artist donated a stained-glass window to the UN Headquarters. That aforementioned self-portrait includes a painting of a man hang-gliding past the Eiffel Tower and depicts this artist with (*) seven fingers. A green angel unfurls a green scroll held by Jesus in this artist’s Yellow Crucifixion, which is often contrasted with this artist’s White Crucifixion. The tree of life appears at the bottom of one of this artist’s paintings, which depicts an upside-down girl playing the violin in his native village of Vitebsk. For 10 points, name this artist who painted I and the Village.
tossups.answer: Mark Chagall [or Moishe Zakharovich Shagal]
tossups.answer_formatted: Mark Chagall [or Moishe Zakharovich Shagal]

tossups.question: “Laissez-Faire” (“LAH-zay-FAIR”) and “Dismissing” are two approaches employed by these people according to psychologists John and Julie Gottman. Psychologist Diana Baumrind argues that these people should adopt a style that is both responsive and demanding. In a book that helped popularize Freud’s theories, these people were told “you know more than you think you do.” Leo Kaner and Bruno Bettelheim promulgated a theory that a lack of warmth in the (*) “refrigerator” version of these people led to autism. Best-selling books written for these people include the What to Expect series and a “Common Sense” guide written by Dr. Benjamin Spock. For 10 points, “helicopter” examples of what types of people are heavily involved in the lives of their children?
tossups.answer: parents [or mothers; or fathers; or moms; or dads; or caregivers; or expectant parents; or parental units; prompt on couples]
tossups.answer_formatted: parents [or mothers; or fathers; or moms; or dads; or caregivers; or expectant parents; or parental units; prompt on couples]

tossups.question: This author created a character who quotes “Nothing in the voice of the cicada intimates how soon it will die” and predicts that his sister Booper will kill him while discussing reincarnation. In a story by this author, Eloise forces her daughter Ramona to sleep in the middle of her bed rather than leave space for imaginary friends like Jimmy Jimmerino. This author of “Teddy” wrote about a man who calls (*) Muriel “Miss Spiritual Tramp of 1948” and goes to the beach with Sybil Carpenter, named Seymour Glass. This author wrote about a boy who calls Sally Hayes after a pimp named Maurice punches him. For 10 points, name this author of “A Perfect Day for Bananafish,” who wrote of the phony-hating Holden Caulfield in The Catcher in the Rye.
tossups.answer: Jerome David Salinger (The second story is “Uncle Wiggily in Connecticut.”)
tossups.answer_formatted: Jerome David Salinger
tossups.metadata: The second story is “Uncle Wiggily in Connecticut.”

tossups.question: The influence of this entity can be reduced by obtaining multiple “lucky” exposures of short duration and combining them in speckle-based techniques. Instruments can correct for low-order perturbations due to this entity using a segmented mirror that tips and tilts in response to incoming wavefront data in the primary application of adaptive optics. Predictions of this entity’s (*) transparency are found alongside cloud cover forecasts in clear sky charts. This entity spreads out the image of objects during astronomical seeing, and its impact is minimal at high elevation observatories like Mauna Kea. For 10 points, the twinkling of stars is caused by what turbulent region separating ground-based telescopes from space?
tossups.answer: Earth’s atmosphere [accept troposphere, stratosphere, or mesosphere; prompt on the sky until “clear sky charts” is read; prompt on air by asking “where?”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Earth’s atmosphere [accept troposphere, stratosphere, or mesosphere; prompt on the sky until “clear sky charts” is read; prompt on air by asking “where?]

tossups.question: This civilization’s history was chronicled in the now-lost books of Sanchuniathon (“san-kyoo-NY-uh-thon”). The scholar Josephine Quinn argued that this civilization “did not in fact exist as a self-conscious collective” but all members did practice a type of infant sacrifice called the tophet. The oldest surviving example of a system created by these people can be found on the Ahiram Epitaph. A king of this civilization named Hiram sent (*) cedar wood to Jerusalem. By the 9th century CE, this civilization controlled Sidon and Byblos. The god Melqart was worshiped in this civilization. Murex snails were harvested to produce a valuable purple dye by, for 10 points, what Mediterranean civilization that invented the alphabet?
tossups.answer: Phoenicians [or Canaanites; or Punic People; accept Carthage; anti-prompt on Tyrian before mentioned]
tossups.answer_formatted: Phoenicians [or Canaanites; or Punic People; accept Carthage; anti-prompt on Tyrian before mentioned]

tossups.question: In fear of being sent to a convent, a character created by this author cross-dresses and then advises the protagonist to cut off an arm and poke out an eye. That play by this author ends with the title character donning a cap and gown and uttering gibberish in fake Latin. For five years, a revised version of another play by this author that had the title (*) Panulphe was banned on threat of excommunication. This author died shortly after appearing in one of his own plays in which Argan agrees to let his daughter marry Cléante so long as Cléante becomes a doctor. He depicted an intervention from the king that saves Orgon’s family from the title religious hypocrite. For 10 points, name this French playwright of The Imaginary Invalid and Tartuffe.
tossups.answer: Molière [or Jean-Baptiste Poquelin]
tossups.answer_formatted: Molière [or Jean-Baptiste Poquelin]

tossups.question: A god of this domain granted a different god the ability to change his size at will in order to keep winds blowing on Earth. A legendary floating idol supported by magnets was housed in a temple dedicated to a god of this domain at Konark. A god of this domain promised Kunti that her son with him would be born with ear-rings and breastplate armor; that child of a god of this domain was the Kaurava ally, (*) Karna. Hanuman mistook a god of this domain for a fruit and was struck by Indra while flying towards him. A god of this domain was also called “Mitra,” the latter of which is cognate with the Iranian “Mithras.” The Hindu god Surya represents, for 10 points, what celestial object?
tossups.answer: the sun
tossups.answer_formatted: the sun

tossups.question: A government serving these people lost significant tax revenue when Section 936 of the tax code was changed, eliminating incentives for pharma companies. 250 schools serving these people under the direction of Julia Keleher closed after an event that prompted at least 160,000 of these people to move. A federal law called Promesa reduced pensions for some of these people after a massive bankruptcy. In 2017, (*) Whitefish Energy was controversially awarded a 300-million-dollar contract to repair an electric grid serving these people after a natural disaster. In 2020, a plurality of these people voted in favor of a referendum on statehood. For 10 points, name these American citizens whose island territory was devastated by Hurricane Maria in 2017.
tossups.answer: Puerto Ricans [or Puerto Rican-Americans; or boricuas; accept people who live in Puerto Rico; prompt on Americans; prompt on Latinos or Latinx people]
tossups.answer_formatted: Puerto Ricans [or Puerto Rican-Americans; or boricuas; accept people who live in Puerto Rico; prompt on Americans; prompt on Latinos or Latinx people]
acceptable: people who live in Puerto Rico

tossups.question: Two answers required. The Cincinnati Gazette circulated pamphlets supporting one of these two people that asked whether the other of them and “a convicted adulteress” “be placed in the highest offices of this free and Christian land?” John Taliaferro accused one of these two men of cannibalizing six militiamen in a pamphlet supporting the other. Supporters of one of these men responded to the “Coffin Handbills” by accusing the other of providing young girls to the Czar while serving as (*) Ambassador to Russia. One of these two men accused the other’s wife Rachel of bigamy, and the other criticized a “corrupt bargain” with Henry Clay. For 10 points, name these two men who ran against each other in the presidential elections of 1824 and 1828.
tossups.answer: Andrew Jackson AND John Quincy Adams [prompt on Adams; do not accept or prompt on “John Adams”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Andrew Jackson AND John Quincy Adams [prompt on Adams; do not accept or prompt on "John Adams"]
acceptable: Andrew Jackson AND John Quincy Adams
Andrew Jackson AND John Quincy Adams

tossups.question: At the end of this work, the orchestra calmly plays a passage that alternates between 3/8 (“three-eight”) and 2/8 time after a section that chaotically shifts between 3/16, 5/16, 4/16, and 2/16 time. In the introduction to this work’s second major division, the brass section accents seemingly random notes while strings repeat stacked E-flat dominant seventh and F-flat major chords. This work’s composer made the last four notes in its bass line spell out (*) “D-E-A-D.” The khorovod is the basis for “Mystic Circles” danced in this ballet. A grace-note-filled bassoon solo opening with a high C begins its first part, “The Adoration of the Earth.” Its second part ends with the “Sacrificial Dance.” For 10 points, name this 1913 ballet by Igor Stravinsky with a riotous premiere.
tossups.answer: The Rite of Spring [or Le sacre du printemps]
tossups.answer_formatted: The Rite of Spring [or Le sacre du printemps]

tossups.question: The narrator watches this character sprinkle white petals in the water in a novel in which he repeatedly plays the same six notes on his flute. This man titles a novel that is set on Speranza and written by Michel Tournier. This character teasingly teaches a bear to “dance” by baiting it onto a narrow tree branch before shooting it. This character worships a god named (*) Benamuckee in that novel. Following the death of his master, this tongueless character goes to live with Susan Barton in J. M. Coetzee’s novel Foe. This character becomes a servant to a man who owns a parrot named Poll after that character saves him from cannibals. For 10 points, Robinson Crusoe names what companion of his for the day of the week he was saved on?
tossups.answer: Friday
tossups.answer_formatted: Friday

tossups.question: The degradation of these organelles is controlled by PINK1 and parkin and has an as-of-yet unknown association with Parkinson’s disease. The majority of these organelles in neurons are distributed in the dendrites. A metalloprotein found in this organelle is commonly used in molecular clock analysis, while another is the standard protein used in animal DNA barcoding. This organelle receives reducing equivalents from the (*) malate-aspartate shuttle. Acute cyanide toxicity inhibits COX in this organelle, which forms Complex IV in this organelle’s inner membrane. A proton gradient found in this organelle drives oxidative phosphorylation. For 10 points, name this organelle that uses ATP synthase to power the cell.
tossups.answer: mitochondria
tossups.answer_formatted: mitochondria

tossups.question: A 2008 exhibition on these artworks featured examples by Erik Demaine, the youngest-ever MIT professor. The complexity of these artworks is governed by the Huzita–Hatori axioms proved by physics professor Robert J. Lang. The Yoshizawa–Randlett system is a way to diagram steps in making these artworks. Since the 1970s, principles from making these artworks have been used to more easily deploy solar panels on satellites and to more efficiently (*) package car airbags. The Pureland form of this art only allows for actions named for mountains and valleys. All of the steps in making these works can be represented in one image in crease pattern diagrams. For 10 points, name these artworks popular in Japan made from folding a piece of paper.
tossups.answer: origami [accept kirigami; prompt on folded paper or paper before the end]
tossups.answer_formatted: origami [accept kirigami; prompt on folded paper or paper before the end]

tossups.question: This politician was told he was better for the “TV generation” than opponent Robert Stanfield in one of several letters exchanged with Marshall McLuhan. This man won a huge electoral majority just days after he was pelted with rotten fruit in a John the Baptist Day parade. Donal Brittain’s documentary The Champions chronicles the rivalry between this head of state and independence advocate René Lévesque (“lay-VEK”). This PM instituted the official (*) bilingualism policy and secured the approval of his country's Charter of Rights and Freedom after succeeding Joe Clark. He declared “Just watch me” during the October Crisis over French separatism. For 10 points, name this Canadian Prime Minister during much of the 1970s, the father of the current PM Justin.
tossups.answer: Pierre Trudeau [or Pierre Elliott Trudeau; prompt on Trudeau]
tossups.answer_formatted: Pierre Trudeau [or Pierre Elliott Trudeau; prompt on Trudeau]

tossups.question: During a dialogue with one of these people who is a woman, Jesus declares that “the hour is coming when neither on this mountain nor in Jerusalem will you worship the Father,” alluding to a controversy over these people’s belief that God’s temple should be on Mount Gerizim. That woman is rebuked for having had five husbands after she asks for “living (*) water” from Jesus, whom she encountered at a well. A parable about one of these people is prompted by a lawyer’s question, “And who is my neighbor?”; in that parable, one of these people who “had compassion” is contrasted with a priest and a Levite. For 10 points, name this ethnoreligious group that is the subject of a parable of Jesus in which a “good” one of them helps a wounded traveler.
tossups.answer: Samaritans [or Shamerim; accept Parable of the Good Samaritan; accept Kutim or Cuthaeans]
tossups.answer_formatted: Samaritans [or Shamerim; accept Parable of the Good Samaritan; accept Kutim or Cuthaeans]

tossups.question: One of these objects displayed in the Seagram Plaza graced the cover of Artforum magazine in 1965. A 1939 expedition led by Matthew Stirling popularized these objects in the US. The 17 known examples of these artifacts were likely made using a combination of drilling and rope-and-water abrasion and may have been transported up to 80 miles from their basalt source in the Tuxtla Mountains. The heaviest of these objects was found in Cobata and unusually has closed (*) eyelids. These objects were made by a culture that also employed the were-jaguar motif. The first of these Preclassical objects was discovered by a farmer in Veracruz; more were found at San Lorenzo. For 10 points, name these large statues thought to be portraits of Olmec rulers.
tossups.answer: Olmec stone colossal heads [prompt on Olmec megaliths or Olmec sculptures; prompt on Olmec thrones]
tossups.answer_formatted: Olmec stone colossal heads [prompt on Olmec megaliths or Olmec sculptures; prompt on Olmec thrones]

tossups.question: One of the most iconic of these objects gets its name from being introduced to the public in February 1955 and has a quilted pattern that intentionally resembles jockey jackets. A bread-inspired one of these objects with an interlocking double-F logo became the first “it” example of one of these objects after appearing in a robbery scene in Sex and the City. One of these objects called the Chanel 2.55 features a linked gold (*) chain. Another of these objects was created after an in-air conversation between Hermès (“air-MEZ”) designer Jean-Louis Dumas and actress Jane Birkin on the need for them to have pockets and handles. For 10 points, name these accessories that include a saddle-shaped one by Dior meant to be worn tight over the shoulder.
tossups.answer: handbags [or a purse; accept Fendi baguette or saddle bag or Chanel bag or Dior bag or clutch; accept Birkin before mentioned; do not accept or prompt on "wallet"]
tossups.answer_formatted: handbags [or a purse; accept Fendi baguette or saddle bag or Chanel bag or Dior bag or clutch; accept Birkin before mentioned; do not accept or prompt on "wallet"]

tossups.question: An s–t cut can be uniquely defined by a single set of these objects because its two partitions are complements to each other. All of these objects but one are assigned an initial label of infinity in an overestimate that is improved by repeated relaxation steps during the Bellman–Ford algorithm. Determining how to reach all of these objects exactly once is the NP-complete Hamiltonian (*) cycle problem. Given a specific one of these objects, the output of Dijkstra’s algorithm spans all of the other ones with minimal distance. The degree of these objects is highest in a complete graph, where they are all adjacent. For 10 points, name these elements of graphs that are connected by edges.
tossups.answer: vertices [singular vertex; accept nodes]
tossups.answer_formatted: vertices [singular vertex; accept nodes]

tossups.question: This country’s 20th-century history is retold in reverse chronology in a story from the recent collection Broken Stars. An author born in this country imagined a society that alternates between Stable and Chaotic times in a novel in which members of the Frontiers of Science are mysteriously killed. In that first entry in the Remembrance of Earth’s Past trilogy by an author from this country, certain scholars commit suicide after (*) Trisolarans invade Earth. A factory worker from this country repeatedly sells the title substance to survive in Chronicle of a Blood Merchant. In 2015, an author born in this country won the Hugo Award for his novel The Three-Body Problem. For 10 points, name this home country of Yu Hua and Liu Cixin (“l’yoh tsuh-sheen”).
tossups.answer: China [or People’s Republic of China; or PRC; do not accept or prompt on “Republic of China”]
tossups.answer_formatted: China [or People’s Republic of China; or PRC; do not accept or prompt on "Republic of China"]

tossups.question: Calculating the enthalpies and entropies of these systems can be simplified through the use of residual properties or departure functions. The temperatures of these systems will change when undergoing a Joule expansion. The acentric factor is one of various empirically determined constants found in cubic (*) equations of state for modeling these systems such as the Peng–Robinson or Redlich–Kwong equations. The compressibility factor characterizes these systems, whose inherent intermolecular forces and particle volumes are accounted for by the a and b parameters of the van der Waals equation. Kinetic molecular theory fails to properly model, for 10 points, what types of gasses that do not perfectly satisfy “PV equals nRT”?
tossups.answer: real gases [or non-ideal gases; or answers indicating gases that do not follow the ideal gas law; accept real fluids; prompt on gases; prompt on fluids; do not accept or prompt on “ideal gases”]
tossups.answer_formatted: real gases [or non-ideal gases; or answers indicating gases that do not follow the ideal gas law; accept real fluids; prompt on gases; prompt on fluids; do not accept or prompt on "ideal gases"]
acceptable: answers indicating gases that do not follow the ideal gas law

tossups.question: Key strategic decisions in this conflict derived from a Motivation and Morale Project overseen by Leon Gouré. An “electronic fence” deployed during this conflict was fooled by enemy soldiers urinating in buckets. During this conflict, the motto “Only you can prevent a forest” was used by participants in Operation Ranch Hand. One side in this conflict sought to win over peasants via the Strategic (*) Hamlet Program. Monsanto and Dow Chemical provided 20 million gallons of herbicides deployed by C-123s during this conflict to cut off a certain trail. American involvement in this conflict was detailed in Daniel Ellsberg’s Pentagon Papers. For 10 points, name this war during which the US targeted guerrillas on the Ho Chi Minh Trail.
tossups.answer: Vietnam War [or Second Indochina War or Resistance War Against America; prompt on American War]
tossups.answer_formatted: Vietnam War [or Second Indochina War or Resistance War Against America; prompt on American War]

bonuses.leadin: While performing tasbīḥ (“tuss-BEEH”), a person utters a phrase consisting of “Subḥān” (“soob-HAHN”) followed by this figure’s name, thus glorifying this figure. For 10 points each:
answers: Fatimah [accept Fatimah al-Zahra or Fatimah az-Zahra]
parts: Name this figure to whom 99 names, like ar-Rahman, or “the Merciful,” and ar-Rahim, or “the Compassionate,” are attributed.
Tasbīḥ is an example of this Islamic devotional practice in which one “remembers” God by repeating His names or short invocations like “Subḥān Allah.” Give the Arabic term.
In the tasbīḥ named after this daughter of Muhammad, a set of 100 prayers are recited, often using misbaḥa beads. This woman married Ali and gave birth to Hasan and Husayn.

bonuses.leadin: This organization was the first independent federal regulatory agency. For 10 points each:
answers: telecom industry [or telephone industry; or telegraph industry; or wireless communications industry; prompt on communications industry]
parts: Identify this federal agency created in 1887 and charged with regulating the practices of railroads. It was disbanded in 1996.
This President signed the bill that established the Interstate Commerce Commission during the first of his two non-consecutive terms in office.
In 1910, the ICC gained authority over companies in this industry. The largest US company in this industry was broken up in 1984, forming new companies such as US West.
answers_formatted: telecom industry [or telephone industry; or telegraph industry; or wireless communications industry; prompt on communications industry]

bonuses.leadin: Most drugs for this disorder do not treat its negative symptoms, which include impairments in memory, emotional expression, and motivation. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this condition that used to be divided into catatonic and paranoid subtypes. Its positive symptoms include disorganized speech, delusions, and hallucinations.
This neurotransmitter’s misregulation is thought to be the main cause of schizophrenia. Most antipsychotic agents target the D2 receptor of this reward pathway neurotransmitter.
This other neurotransmitter binds to NMDA receptors that modulate dopamine levels. Decreasing its signaling with ketamine or PCP mimics symptoms of schizophrenia.

bonuses.leadin: The Quechan (“queh-CHAHN”) tribe briefly operated a profitable monopoly on helping 49ers ford the Colorado River at a crossing with this name. For 10 points each:
answers: Ford Motor Company [accept Henry Ford Museum] (The newspaper is The Dearborn Independent.)
parts: Identify this city, later connected to the Quechan reservation by the Ocean-to-Ocean bridge. Delmer Daves’ directed a 1957 Western titled 3:10 to [This City].
Yuma names a city, a county, and a desert in this state, whose other attractions include Saguaro National Park west of Tucson (“TOO-sawn”).

Arizona’s many Proving Grounds include one in Yuma run by the US Army and one in Wittmann owned by this company. This company’s founder built a museum for “American Innovation” and once published a newspaper from a facility in River Rouge (“rooj”).
metadata: The newspaper is The Dearborn Independent.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about Poet Laureates of the United Kingdom:
parts: This poet of “I Wandered Lonely as a Cloud” and “Tintern Abbey” started the trend of loosening the expectations for the Poet Laureate’s duties when he was appointed in 1843.
Philip Larkin declined the offer of becoming the Poet Laureate in 1984, about thirteen years after he wrote this poem in which he advises, “And don't have any kids yourself.”
This poet behind the collection Rapture became the first woman and the first LGBTQ+ poet to be appointed Poet Laureate in 2009.

bonuses.leadin: This director’s film Woman in the Moon contains the first onscreen countdown to a rocket launch. For 10 points each:
answers: Fritz Lang [or Friedrich Christian Anton Lang]
synchronized sound [or sync sound; or sound film; accept talkies or talking pictures; accept more specific technologies such as Vitaphone]
parts: Identify this German director who allegedly turned down an offer to head the Nazi’s film division. This director of Metropolis later criticized the Nazi regime in Hangmen Also Die!
The advent of this technology allowed Lang to depict the protagonist of M whistling “In the Hall of the Mountain King.” This technology was popularized in the US by The Jazz Singer.

Late in his life, Lang went back to West Germany to make a final film about the “thousand eyes” of this character. This character’s “testament” is detailed in a 1933 thriller in which he outlines his criminal plans from a mental asylum.
answers_formatted: synchronized sound [or sync sound; or sound film; accept talkies or talking pictures; accept more specific technologies such as Vitaphone]
acceptable: more specific technologies such as Vitaphone

bonuses.leadin: During this event, two officers raced each other to decapitate 100 civilians as fast as possible. For 10 points each:
answers: Rape of Nanking [or Nanking Massacre; or Rape of Nanjing; or Nanjing Massacre]
Unit 731 [or Detachment 731; or 731 Regiment; or Manshu Detachment 731; or Kamo Detachment; prompt on Ishii Unit or Ishii Detachment or Ishii Company]
parts: Name this Japanese war crime beginning in 1937 in which General Iwane Matsui (“ee-wah-neh ma-tsoo-ee”) allowed his men to murder hundreds of thousands of civilians in the capital of the Republic of China.
During the Rape of Nanking, a branch of this research group forced transmission of syphilis. This group’s leader Shiro Ishii escaped execution by turning over data about germ warfare.
Many members of the Imperial Japanese Army convicted of war crimes during the Rape of Nanking are controversially interred at this Tokyo shrine. Shinzo Abe visited this shrine in 2020.
answers_formatted: Rape of Nanking [or Nanking Massacre; or Rape of Nanjing; or Nanjing Massacre]
Unit 731 [or Detachment 731; or 731 Regiment; or Manshu Detachment 731; or Kamo Detachment; prompt on Ishii Unit or Ishii Detachment or Ishii Company]

bonuses.leadin: In a play by Sławomir Mrożek (“SWAH-vo-meer m’RO-zhek”), a member of this profession is pressured to commit crimes in fear of losing his job. For 10 points each:
answers: police officer [or cops; or inspectors: do not accept or prompt on “detective”]
Ireland [or Republic of Ireland; or Éire] (The authors are Flann O’Brien and Samuel Beckett.)
parts: Give this profession shared by Bertozzo and other characters who are repeatedly tricked by the Maniac in Dario Fo’s play The Accidental Death of an Anarchist.
Fo and Mrożek, like Eugène Ionesco, are often grouped with this style of theatre that responded to the meaninglessness of life by depicting bizarre and nonsensical actions.

Sergeant Pluck is obsessed with bicycles in The Third Policeman, an absurdist novel from this country. A biking accident forces two characters to live in trash cans in an absurd play written in French by an author born in this country.
answers_formatted: police officer [or cops; or inspectors: do not accept or prompt on “detective]
metadata: The authors are Flann O’Brien and Samuel Beckett.

bonuses.leadin: This deity’s round sanctuary in Rome was contrasted with the mostly square buildings in the Forum. For 10 points each:
answers: Cybele (“SIB-uh-lee”) [or Cyebebe; or Agdistis; or Kybele]
parts: Identify this goddess whose virginal female servants were relieved of their obligations to their patria potestas. Those priestesses maintained an eternal flame sacred to this hearth goddess.
This other important cult deity for Roman women has a Latin name deriving from the Phrygian word for “mountain.” The Romans referred to this deity as “great mother.”

Cybele’s notorious eunuch (“YOO-nuck”) priests, the galli, castrated themselves in commemoration of this consort of Cybele. This god was born from the discarded male half of Cybele, who was originally hermaphroditic.

bonuses.leadin: This conformation of a ring-shaped molecule has the lowest energy, unlike the local minimum twist-boat conformation. For 10 points each:
answers: chair conformer [accept chair flip or word forms like chair flipping]
chemical bonds [or covalent bonds; accept single bonds or sigma bonds]
parts: Name this conformation of cyclohexane. A namesake “flip” converts between the two versions of this conformation, which differ in which specific hydrogens are in which positions.

Each substituent on cyclohexane is in one of these two positions and swaps between them during a chair flip. The anomeric effect describes the preference of heteroatoms for one of these positions over the other.
Transitions between conformations involve rotations about these structures, which are formed by sharing electrons between adjacent atoms.
answers_formatted: chair conformer [accept chair flip or word forms like chair flipping]
chemical bonds [or covalent bonds; accept single bonds or sigma bonds]

bonuses.leadin: Four to five sympathetic strings run under the four main strings of the Hardanger fiddle native to this country. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country home to the halling folk dance. Three hallings appear in the Lyric Pieces of a composer from this country.

This Norwegian composer of Peer Gynt wrote a G minor string quartet that uses the same “falling minor second, falling minor third” motif as the beginning of his more famous A minor piano concerto, which was inspired by Clara Wieck.
Grieg’s piano concerto opens with a roll on one of these percussion instruments. Carl Nielsen’s “Inextinguishable” fourth symphony features a duel between these instruments.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about the early exploration of Australia and New Zealand.
answers: Burke and Wills Expedition [accept Robert O’Hara Burke and William John Wills; accept in either order; prompt on partial answer]
parts: The state of Victoria purchased 24 camels from India for this expedition across mainland Australia. This expedition, named for its two leaders, surveyed from Melbourne all the way to the Gulf of Carpentaria.
This explorer’s circumnavigation of New Zealand showed that there might exist a continent on the South Pole. This explorer’s crew named Botany Bay and he died in Hawaii.
The first Europeans to sight New Zealand were in this man’s crew. After members of his crew were killed by the Māori in Golden Bay in 1642, this Dutch explorer renamed the bay to Murderer’s Bay.
answers_formatted: Burke and Wills Expedition [accept Robert O’Hara Burke or William John Wills; accept in either order; prompt on partial answer]

bonuses.leadin: In this novel, Wally is paralyzed by an infection he catches hiding from the Japanese after his plane is shot down in Burma. For 10 points each:
answers: John Irving [or John Winslow Irving; or John Wallace Blunt Jr.]
parts: Identify this novel in which the protagonist Homer Wells succeeds Dr. Wilbur Larch in running the St. Cloud’s Orphanage and its secret abortion facility.
The Cider House Rules is a novel by this bear-loving American author of The World According to Garp and A Prayer for Owen Meany.
The name of the character Hester Eastman in A Prayer for Owen Meany is one of several elements Irving drew from this novel, whose protagonist Hester Prynne receives the title punishment for adultery.
answers_formatted: John Irving [or John Winslow Irving; or John Wallace Blunt Jr.]

bonuses.leadin: The final place setting in Judy Chicago’s The Dinner Party is set for this artist. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this artist who painted the title New York City skyscraper in Radiator Building. This artist made fun of “Great American Painting” by painting Cow’s Skull: Red, White and Blue.
O’Keeffe is perhaps best known for her many paintings of these objects, such as Petunia No. 2 and Calla Lily Turned Away.
This feminist art group described O’Keeffe as “the woman who hated flowers” in their Bedside Companion to the History of Western Art. Members of this group wear animal masks to hide their identity.

bonuses.leadin: This thinker proposed an early version of the idea that scientific hypotheses cannot be tested in isolation from their “bundled” counterparts. For 10 points each:
answers: Pierre Duhem [or Pierre Maurice Marie Duhem; accept Duhem–Quine thesis]
parts: Name this physicist and philosopher of science who co-names that thesis with W. V. O. Quine.

Duhem agreed with this book’s distinction between the spirits of finesse and geometry. A thought experiment in this book considers a gambling scenario with potentially infinite gain and a finite chance to lose.
Duhem followed much of the thought of this Jansenist philosopher, whose namesake wager appears in his Pensées.
answers_formatted: Pierre Duhem [or Pierre Maurice Marie Duhem; accept Duhem–Quine thesis]

bonuses.leadin: The midpoint of these things defines the pitch circle, a hypothetical surface in which they do not exist. For 10 points each:
answers: teeth [prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, gears by asking “what smaller component is part of those?”]
parts: Name these components of larger parts that often have an involute profile to restrict contact to a single point. The number of these things is the denominator of the module.
When two of these devices have equal module, their teeth intermesh and they can smoothly rotate to transmit torque.

This term for trains of connected gears is more commonly used to refer to the part of the drivetrain containing the gearbox. Automobile drivers may engage the clutch while shifting to move between gears in the device of this name.
answers_formatted: teeth [prompt on prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, gears by asking “what smaller component is part of those?]
promptable: prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, gears

bonuses.leadin: The song “Jolly Jack of Dover” expresses the sentiment against these people in Great Britain at the time of the passage of the Aliens Act of 1793. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this French term for people, usually nobles, who fled from the French Revolution.
The first wave of émigrés fled France after the storming of this Parisian political prison on July 14th, 1789.
Clergy who did not leave France or agree to have their estates confiscated were forcibly deported to French Guiana, the location of this penal colony later home to Alfred Dreyfus.

bonuses.leadin: The adman Matthew Biggs is the protagonist of Kenneth Calhoun’s novel Black Moon, in which almost all characters suffer from this condition. For 10 points each:
answers: Gabriel García Márquez [or Gabriel José de la Concordia García Márquez; prompt on Gabo; prompt on Gabito; prompt on Márquez]
he dies [or a death; or murder; accept Chronicle of a Death Foretold]
parts: Identify this condition that, along with amnesia, afflicts Rebecca, who is adopted by the Buendia family in Chapter 3 of One Hundred Years of Solitude. Soon after, the whole town of Macondo is afflicted with this condition.
One Hundred Years of Solitude is a novel by this Colombian Nobel Laureate.

Melquíades cures the insomnia plague but soon becomes the first person in Macondo to suffer this fate. Father Amador and Colonel Aponte forget to tell Santiago Nasar of this fate in a García Márquez novella titled for it.
answers_formatted: Gabriel García Márquez [or Gabriel José de la Concordia García Márquez; prompt on Gabo; prompt on Gabito; prompt on Márquez]
he dies [or a death; or murder; accept Chronicle of a Death Foretold]
acceptable: Gabriel José de la Concordia García Márquez

bonuses.leadin: In one of the lectures collected in Lezioni accademiche, this scientist was the first to propose that wind was caused by differences in air temperatures between two regions. For 10 points each:
answers: v² + 2ad [or v-squared plus 2 a d; or equivalents]
parts: Name this Italian mathematician and physicist, inventor of the mercury barometer.
Torricelli created the first laboratory example of this state within a 1643 barometer. Otto von Guericke invented a pump named for this low-pressure state.

Sometimes, Torricelli’s name refers to a kinematic equation that finds the final velocity of an object that is moving in constant acceleration, which disregards the time interval. Give the expression for final velocity squared in terms of the initial velocity v, acceleration a, and displacement d.

bonuses.leadin: One of these texts by Sharon Traweek titled Beamtimes and Lifetimes examines the world of particle physicists. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify these anthropological texts that contain descriptive studies of societies.

This Polish anthropologist declared that “ethnographic work should deal with the totality of all social, cultural and psychological aspects of the community” in the intro to his book Argonauts of the Western Pacific.

Several anthropologists traveled to this island in the 1950s as part of the Modjokuto Project. For a 1987 ethnography, Ward Keeler spent several years on this island living with a practitioner of wayang, a type of shadow puppetry.

bonuses.leadin: In reference to this policy, Politburo member Yegor Ligachev warned “it is not wise to enter a room if you do not know the way out.” For 10 points each:
answers: television [or TV; accept answers like cable television or satellite television; prompt on broadcast technology]
Latvia [or Republic of Latvia; or Latvija]
parts: Name this policy of increased government transparency complemented by a policy of economic liberalization called perestroika.
Glasnost-era programs such as Vzglyad (“viz-glyat”) used this technology to publicize Stalinist crimes. RT primarily uses this technology to spread pro-Putin messages.

Glasnost helped pro-independence parties in this country such as the Tautas Fronte (“TAU-tahss FRON-teh”) gain power. Post-independence, the government of Valdis Dombrovskis fell after a building collapsed in this country’s capital, killing 54 people in 2013.
answers_formatted: television [or TV; accept answers like cable television or satellite television; prompt on broadcast technology]
